comments.commentBody:
Very good - you could find one Jew who committed a terrorist act, which neatly balances out the thousands (tens of thousands?) of murders, bombings, mall shootings, school massacres, acid attacks, head loppings, and on, and on, and endlessly on.

Yes, for a period of time the Middle East did lead the world in sciences, math, poetry, and more. How did they let themselves become so debased? Have you looked at the time frame of the rise of Islamist identity and correlated it with the decline of the society?

This is one of those good news, bad news announcements. As other have noted, average wages declined by 0.2%. I'm not an economist. How does this happen? Is it due to the job creation mostly being at the bottom end such retail or other services? Is it due to people entering the work force taking jobs at a lower salary than those who left these same jobs? Then didn't the nation's aggregate payroll decline in Dec.? How can a reduction by 0.2% in average wages possibly be good for our economy?

As usual, the "moderate" voices of Islam are deafening in their silence. Where are the strenuous condemnations of this senseless violence from within the Muslim community? Do the Iranians condone this violence? Do the Pakistanis? The Saudis? The Indonesians? There has been not a word, as far as I can tell. The only conclusion that can be drawn is that they approve of it.

Mr. Hollande of France says that the attacks had “nothing to do with Islam.” What Islam is he talking about? The only Islamic voices we hear in the world today are the voices of murder, mayhem, anarchy and insanity. We very rarely hear even mild condemnation from those within Islam against their extremist elements. As such we have no choice but to take the violent voice of Islam at its word.

The time for denial and coddling is over. It is long past time for the West to take the offensive in order to defend the values we hold - which took centuries and much blood to obtain. If the path of Islam is to be unrestrained violence and endless murder and bloodshed against the West, then the West has no choice but to expel this violent ideology from its midst once and for all.

It has become a matter of survival, and those that are devoted to the destruction of our free societies cannot be permitted to remain in our free societies.

Cody McCall, no one wants war. But just when do we end the jihadists? They're not going to go away of their own free will.
There is already a world war between Islam and the West. We all need to fully grasp that. This is not going to end - not without considerable violence. And if the West does not win then say bye-bye to freedom, to decency, to respect, to morality, to the ability think and speak for ourselves.
And I speak as a progressive liberal.

Bush didn't ask for 9/11, but he responded forcefully and took the war to them which kept America attack free for the remainder of his presidency.   He freed Iraq from a tyrant and Muslims in turn proved they are incapable of peaceful self government.   Now they are proving they are equally incapable of living peacefully in the civilized world.

It will be interesting to see how France in particular and the West in general respond.  Will we be smart and measured and targeted?  Or some spate of mindless violence (see Bush administration) that exacerbates an already tense situation.  These jihadists are trying their best to foment a world-wide war between Islam and the West.  Let's not make it easier for them.
I hope the next cover of Charlie Hebdo is the bravest and most honest ever done.

In the category of "so obvious we don't bother to mention it" is the point that while capital and goods flow easily from country to country labour does not.  Even within countries labour cannot move to higher wage areas as easily as capital can move to low wage areas.  So this "theory of everything" includes some of the forces that work to further the division of rich from poor.

One requirement of religious freedom by first amendment is to be able to practice it without mockery, ridicule, or concealed humor from the neighbor etc
----------
Uhhh... no .. that is not a requirement in the 1st Amendment. At least not in the U.S. We can make fun of Buddha, Christ, Mohammed, Joseph Smith and Vishnu all we want and those who are offended can shout, cry and stomp their feet and that is as far as it should go. If you really have "true faith" then you shouldn't have a meltdown because somebody called our daddy names.

I think you are entirely missing the point here...unless you think bumper stickers and license plates are equivalent, in which case you are missing a much more basic point. So what if it's on the plate? Are you suggesting that NAMBLA deserves their own custom license plate? Is there any point at which the message on the plate crosses a line? Who is to make that decision? Let's remember that the specialty group also shares in the proceeds. So it is in fact a public-private joint venture.

The state, if it must allow specialty plates, has every interest and right to arbitrarily decide which groups and implicit messages it will permit. They probably should never have opened this can of worms in the first place, but now that they have, let's not fall victim to silly false equivalences, and worse, neo-libertarian arguments about entitlement and "freedoms".

Bumper stickers exist precisely so you can fly your personal freak flag. There is nothing in the Constitution that says you are entitled to put that message on your license plate as well.

In Ohio, at least, the state does not make money from specialty plates sponsored by private groups. They charge extra for the specialty plates because they are more expensive to make, and the rest of it is funneled to the organization that requested the plate.
As this editorial clearly shows, the state legislatures must approve the messages that go onto vanity plates.  I take that to mean that the state does, in fact, endorse those messages.

All of this and more can and does appear on bumper stickers and window decals.

So what if its on the license plate itself? The state makes money that benefits all of us. They'll have it on the rear of their car either way.

Nobody thinks the state endorses it. It is like a lottery -- the state does it for the money like everybody else.
Islam is how it is practiced. So there are serious issues within this religion. To deny it is a form of wishful fantasy.

It is not, and yet it is. Parisians now need to take time to process and heal from what has happened in their city, and perhaps then we shall see whether their spirit of grief and solidarity with the first set of victims can grow to encompass this second set as well. With good reason, Jews sadly cannot depend on being included in that embrace, and so we wait for something other than silence or opprobrium.
FYI, The Guardian has announced a donation of 100,000 GBP to allow Charlie Hebdo to keep publishing; Google is donating 300,000 USD.

Yet for decades now the message that SPORTS and drinking are inextricably linked has been promulgated like no other cultural norm. I'd wager more people watch more sports,more often then they do movies. Plus there might be one drinking scene in a movie, where during a game on TV there are dozens of adverts condoning the need for beer (and junk food - another cultural, social norming practice) and lots of it, often in revolutionary containers that "deliver it faster" down the gullet, in order for the game viewer to get the full FAN and viewing experience. I think the few drinking movie scenes are drowned out by the professional-sports and beer advertising leviathan.

comments.userLocation: Lost in the wilds of Maryland
comments.commentBody:
Social norming can have a tremendous effect on reducing drinking in college. When a group of students decides that getting drunk is an ugly, stupid and a not cool thing to do, and when they display that attitude to others, it can greatly reduce the desire to drink to excess. When people treat drunkenness as just part of the scene, "man, was I wasted last night" and it is treated as fun, a big joke, then people think they can get away with it and face no social penalty. Let one young woman tell one young man, "I don't date people who drink like that" and the word would spread like wildfire. Unfortunately, the idea of women's liberation has gone to the point where it is required that women be as stupid as men. Progress.

Movies have a huge impact in this social norming. "Let's do shots!", one of the most aggressive and dangerous practices in drinking, is said in movies as often or more than, "I love you". No one, to my knowledge, has called down the movie industry for promoting and glamorizing this form of "get drunk quick" behavior. Movies make people feel comfortable about getting drunk and portray it as a normal practice. This makes people watching the movies feel good about themselves and willing to spend money to see more movies.

Drinking replaced cigarettes as a constant movie crutch.

By the way, Maimonides wasn't the only one with a good quote about probabilities. Bob Dylan sang, "I believe in the impossible/you know that I do"

Doug Terry

Has anybody notified Islamic terrorists organizations what happens if the west takes off their kid gloves?  They are backing the entire civilized world into a corner and that is not a good long term strategy for the well being of terrorist organizations or countries.  They don't know it yet.  But they are pissants on the world stage. The President of Egypt was right to warn his countrymen in his speech today.

No one is obligated to accept ideas they find repugnant nor  to placate those with whom they  vehemently disaree.  'Good manners" too often means acquesence to the status quo for the sake of avoiding conflict. The response to offending speech is counter  speech not censorship and even the most sacred cow is fair game in an open society.

Yes, of course, who wouldn't agree with you. It's of course the victims who are to blame. Christians who they murdered egged them on by celebrating a different God and Muslims of other sects who they kill are asking for it on the basis of having made the wrong liturgical mistake in the 7th century AD. And then there's of course the Magician they just beheaded in Syria. He was accused of sorcery. Certainly he got what he deserved.

Oh yes, and let's not forget the Jews. They certainly had it coming. They should certainly have realized that buying a pound of salami at a kosher butcher was asking for it.
Also, ask the Africans (and Europeans, for that matter) who for centuries were captured and carried off into slavery by Muslim slave traders.

Agree. There are a lot of facilities and resources that are built-in in Boston already, so we don't need to build everything from ground up. And we have lots of local experience hosting big events. There's a saying that the Game would be like hosting Boston Marathon everyday, consecutively for 17 days. That isn't so bad. And for those who worries about the local support, they should go out and see how local support (of all the inconvenience like road closure and detour) is for the Boston Marathon every year to get some appreciation of it.

"[s]eventeen days of inconvenience and excitement..."

All of that infrastructure doesn't just spring up like mushrooms after a rainstorm and then magically disappear. If we were to host the Olympics we would have to live with that inconvenience and price for more than a decade. Try living in Boston during the Marathon or even a Red Sox game and you'll see just a tiny picture of how poorly designed our infrastructure is for this sort of thing. We've already had one Big Dig this century and we continue to suffer the cost of it every time we experience yet another broken-down T ride. We hosted the Democratic convention in 2004 and that wasn't a boon to local business either. With the Marathon bombings and subsequent FBI investigation we've already experienced what it's like to live with just Boylston Street locked down for "security" for a week. For a city with 400 years of history, our politicians seem to forget a whole lot of it.

Furthermore, what possible "excitement" would we see anyway? It's not like John from Southie is ever going to get tickets to an event. Joey would have to watch it on television or the web, which means that it might as well be hosted anywhere, preferably in some jumped-up republic that thinks hosting the Olympics might give them status.
Tell you what:  let's do it on Kauai instead.

Oh come on, Boston is a great city to host an Olympics.  The harbor and Charles river are natural resources.  The Marathon is world renowned. Would an improved subway, with a Circle Line be an improvement for decades to come, yes.  Is seventeen days of inconvenience and excitement, hosting the worlds finest athletes a once in a lifetime opportunity, absolutely.  Get on board and enjoy it.

"And any residual benefit from hosting the Games would likely be as ephemeral as a rhythmic gymnastics routine."  Although there is evidence aplenty to support this sentiment--the Beijing 'birds nest' anybody?--it will probably happen anyway.  The IOC is corrupt, there are profits to be made, and corporate interests always prevail over common sense.  But, maybe my Boston brethren will prove me wrong.  One can only hope.
No need for the apology. I live in Boston, and I'd love to have the Game here. Surely it won't be easy feat, nothing in life does. But getting busy for 17 days? We can handle it.

Oh, yeah? Take Patriot's Day and multiply it by a factor of 100 and stretch that over 17 days, not to mention the cost of years of preparation and the fact that public transportation cannot get you from north of the city to west of the city without transferring through South Station. You probably just want to rent your home for the games and spend that summer in Canada.

My sympathies to the residents of Boston -a truly bad idea, anyhow if by some miracle Boston does host the Olympics get out of town and come stay in Manhattan perhaps you will catch a break in the MLB schedule and the Sox will be playing at the Stadium

I mourn for the dead and those who loved them.

I also plead for calm, wise perspective by all parties involved while considering this tragedy. It is sad these people died but many die every day. These circumstances happen to be published so they captured the world's attention. Is any one death for any reason any less dreadful?

Since time immemorial, there have been religious extremist fanatics ignorantly willing to "die for their God or their religion" and sadly, kill others with this mindset. There will be more of these in the future but the Earth's rotation will not wobble any differently. I take solace in Buddhist perspectives via the Four Noble Truths at times like these.

Life involves some amount of suffering, physical and emotional, from the moment we are born to the moment we die. Life is impermanent. The key to suffering is to recognize unhealthy attachment. We can and should love, but within realistic understanding so we do not foster for ourselves any needless suffering. Mother Teresa, Gandhi and the Buddha understood this and cared with open hearts and never any hatred.

Two Buddha thoughts may help at this time?

“Holding on to anger is like grasping a hot coal with the intent of throwing it at someone else; you are the one who gets burned.”

“Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.”

People are losing sight of the fact that these are criminal acts. The politics are debated by intellectuals who are law abiding citizens. The murderers of July 7-9 lost the right to political legitimacy when they picked up a gun.

Eye-popping grid, and I knew it was Joe's before reading the byline.  I also knew DIDI CONN without having thought of her in over 30 years.  And SAGE HENS I got off the _EHE_ though I never heard a Nevadan called one (hard to pin down that one online).  Overall, probably a shade quicker than average.  Great job with the stacks on the perimeter.
Robert Darnton's short essay LAUGHTER AND TERROR, which appears in the NYRblog today, is worth reading. Here is the link: http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2015/jan/09/charlie-hebdo-laughter-...
Exactly. Well put.

Wrong.  There is zero comparison to Muslims in today's Europe and Jews in Germany. Jews were not killing in the name of their god.  There's no excuse for governments to sit passively by waiting for the next attact.  They must lean forward and not be constrained by rules of engagement that cowardly barbarians don't subscribe to.  The only valid comparison to Nazis Germany is how civilized nations confronted it. We won WWII for one reason only.  The civilized world was willing to use any means necessary to confront evil.  Unfortunately,  it seems like we must do the moral equivalent of fire bombing Dresden to secure the peace.

"The events are already resonating in French politics and could further strengthen a surging far-right party, the National Front, which has railed against what it says is the failure of immigrants, and Muslims in particular, to integrate into French society."

I would urge the French to remember what happened in their neighboring country about 82 years ago, when a far-right party gained power by blaming the country's problems on an ethnic minority.
